Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snjórinn einkennist af umhleypingum og ísingu á yfirborði þar sem mörg þunn íslög eru ofaná hvoru öðru með lítilsháttar snjó á milli (prinspóló) efstu 7 cm brotnuðu og þjöppuðust á fyrstu 5 höggunum en á 19 höggi varð hreint brot í gegnum stöpulinn á 39 cm dýpi neðst í laginu sem er kantaðir kristallar. lagið ofaná frá 11 cm niður á 33 er mjög mikill styrkur í því náði ekki að brjóta þetta þegar ég hoppaði á snjónum fyrir ofan gryfju þegar ég var að ganga frá henni.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Ski tracks on slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope;
We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Surface was small surface hoar on top of barely noticeable, VERY thin, easily breakable (with hands) crust. I'm still learning grain types, so I didn't officially ID grain types in the profile, but I believe there are faceting grains in the top 20cm. That same layer had moist snow (due to constant high temps?). With the upcoming storms (fingers crossed!) I'd keep an eye on layers 105-93cm, 90-63cm, and snow above and below multiple crusts. Basically the top 65cm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Isolated wind slabs from 23 November. Slab depths 10-20cm. Longest shooting crack length = 3 m. In non-winded areas the top 10-20cm was moving easily as facet sluffs on slopes > 35 degrees. Very weak snowpack, but with very isolated 2m -3m slabs the hazard remains low... for now.
Sticky Interface between the new snow and the crust in hand shear tests. Whole snowpack somewhat moist.

Location.range: Banff, Yoho and Kootenay National Parks
Location.name: Dolomite shoulder

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Wx started clear with scattered cirrostratus in all cardinal directions. By 1300 MST, altocumulus and altostratus clouds developed from the S to W, and covered 4/8 of sky. Lenticular cloud formation observed to the SE. Wind speeds and gusts increasing from W to NW.

Sheltered area for the pit, but winds were beginning to ramp along the more exposed areas on the ridge. Myriad of crusts breaking down in pack, most evident one here was the thermal crust up 52cm from the ground. Result of CT21 SC @18cm from the ground was surprising given its shear quality. The shallow snow is weakening here near the ground.

Location.name: Goat's Eye Study Plot

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope; Poor pit location;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit location just below Arrowhead Bowl, brutal, strong winds deterred us from going higher. Rain on snow event seemed to have solidified the bottom 20cm of snow. Strong westerly winds were blowing down all east facing basins. Noticed recent avalanche debris in October Bowl to the south. Snowpack is still thin in places it has not been wind drifted, variable conditions.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Collapsing, localized; Instability rapidly rising;
Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Very layered snowpack with many different crusts. Natural avalanche, looked cornice triggered on different N/NE aspect near ridge line at ~ 10,000 ft. elevation. Snow pit layers of most concern are two Knife crusts near the surface (80 cm and 76 cm above ground respectively) and a buried layer of small facets 25-45 cm above the ground.
location +/- 100 feet

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on different slopes;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Above avalanche bowl. Stable. New snow bonding well to melt-freeze crust which is breaking down.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit done on SW. side Blueberry Knoll 150V feet below ridgetop. Found very reactive 12cm thick windslab on surface underlain by facet layer. ECTPV wind slab slid on underlying facet layer overlying MF crust.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 48-45 crust noticeably reactive on the skin back to office, lots of wumphing.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Right side up snowpack. Shallow snowpack is progressively weakening through the high pressure to the point where natural facet sluffs are initiating off of exposed rocks. Basal crust is supportable in some areas - in some areas two crusts separated by well developed facets. No significant wind transport in recent two weeks - no slab present.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in near treeline terrain. Upper and mid snowpack are weakening via the faceting process.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: A couple inches of rimed new snow capping K-hard rime/rain crust from11-12. Snow cover only above about 8500' and very thin. Oct. snow only on north quadrant.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Westerly winds were blowing today, moving lots of snow along the high ridgelines. Snowpit was in a relatively deeper snowpack location. Was typically finding about HS 40-60cms. Near and along the ridgeline, I was getting lots of subtle collapsing and cracking (not making much sound- muffled by the new snow?), but the cracks were traveling 30' or more in many places.
